oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gendered Emotion Management and Perceptions of Affective Culture in a Military Nonprofit Organization
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Callahan, Jamie L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This paper explores the emotion work conducted by men and women in a nonprofit organization and their perceptions of the feeling rules in the organization. The study found that qualitative differences showing that women performed more emotion work than men were supported by a quantitative survey that measured perceptions of affective culture. Specifically, women were more likely than men to say that the culture of the organization required members to be affectively neutral (p<.007).
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Education Leadership Research Center, Texas A&M University
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Advancing Women in Leadership Journal; Vol. 21 (2006 Summer)
